title: Everyday English Course 36
description: Improve your English comprehension skills through short everyday conversations and situational dialogues.

sections.title: Section 1: English Practice
sections.description: Learn to understand and respond to basic English dialogues used in daily situations.

questionTemplates.text:
M: Hurry up. It is time for TV.
W: What are we going to watch?
M: A football match between Germany and Italy. It will be exciting.
W: But I am not interested in, football. I like to see a TV film.
M: Oh. no. You can see a TV film any other day.
W: There will he oilier football games any other day.
M: But this game is the most important of the season.
W: If you insist on watching the game, I will go.
M: Where are you going? Are you annoyed with me?
W: No. I am going to the cinema.
{a}

answerOptions: They can't get agreed on what they are going to do.
They can't get agreed on what program they are going to watch on TV.
They can't get agreed on when to watch TV.
instances.correctAnswer: They can't get agreed on what program they are going to watch on TV.

variables.a: What can't they agree on?

answerOptions: They decide to watch the game together.
They decide to go to the cinema.
They decide to do different things separately.
instances.correctAnswer: They decide to do different things separately.

variables.a: What do they decide to do late?

questionTemplates.text:
M: So, Macy, how was your holiday?
W: Oh, we loved it. Tom liked Germany best, but France was my favorite.
M: So did Rachael finally go with you?
W: No, she wasn't able to. She was called away for a business trip to China.
M: That's a pity. So where exactly did you go and visit?
W: Well, we traveled all over, Italy, Spain and Holland; we even bathed in a Swiss lake
M: You did, really?
{a}

variables.a: What are the two speakers talking about?
Where did Rachel go?

questionTemplates.text:
W: Where's Cecilia, Mark?
M: I'm not sure. She finishes school at 3. Maybe she went to Joyce's. She knows she has to come home before 5.
W: It's 5:30 now.
M: Maybe she forgot her watch.
W: Well, someone has to wash the dishes. The kitchen's a mess.
M: I can go to Joyce's. I know her address.
W: That's OK. We don't need her. You can wash the dishes.
{a}

variables.a: Where are the two speakers?
Where's the mess?

questionTemplates.text:
W: What's going on between you and Charlie? Did you have a fight or something?
M: No, but I can't stand him anymore. He is the worst roommate I've ever had. He never cleans up after himself and he is always listening to loud music when I try to get some sleep.
W: Why don't you have a heart-to-heart talk with him?
M: I've tried, but it didn't work. Maybe you can talk to him. After all, you are his good friend.
{a}

answerOptions: Keeping his room clean every day.

variables.a: What seems to be the man's problem?
What does the woman suggest the man do?

questionTemplates.text:
W: Good morning, sir. Can I help you?
M: Yes. I'd like a single room with a bath.
W: Do you have a reservation, sir?
M: No.
W: OK. Please wait a second. I'll find a room for you.
{a}

variables.a: Where does the conversation take place?
What is the man doing?
What does the man suggest the woman do?
Where are the two persons?
What does the man want the woman to do?

answerOptions: It will take about one month to repair the watch.
The watch is no longer worth repairing.
It is a good idea to keep the old watch.
instances.correctAnswer: The watch is no longer worth repairing.

variables.a: What does the man mean?
What is the weather like?

sections.title: Section 2: English Practice
sections.description: Learn to understand and respond to basic English dialogues used in daily situations.

variables.a: Where are the two speakers?
What are they talking about?

answerOptions: It will start at three this afternoon.
It will start at three tomorrow afternoon.
It will start at eight tomorrow morning.
instances.correctAnswer: It will start at eight tomorrow morning.

variables.a: What do you know about the lecture?

questionTemplates.text:
W: I wish I knew the times of the trains to London. But our phone's out of order.
M: Don't worry, Grandma. I'll find out for you on the Internet.
W: Thank you!
{a}

variables.a: What is the man going to do?
Will the woman turn off the clock?

answerOptions: He has just cleaned his desk.
He has just finished dancing with his friend.
He has just finished his homework.
instances.correctAnswer: He has just finished his homework.

variables.a: What has Peterson just finished?

answerOptions: Her car is better than his.
Her car is not so good.
instances.correctAnswer: Her car is not so good.

variables.a: What's the man's opinion of the woman's car?
Where are they talking?

questionTemplates.text:
W: This is a beautiful park. Shall we come again tomorrow?
M: Don't we have to go shopping?
W: We can do that in the afternoon, and come here in the morning.
M: OK. And let's bring Hilda and Julia with us.
{a}

answerOptions: They are going to the park.
They are going to the cinema with their children.

variables.a: Where are they going to do tomorrow afternoon?
What are the speakers talking about?

sections.title: Section 3: English Practice
sections.description: Learn to understand and respond to basic English dialogues used in daily situations.

variables.a: When will the concert finish?
Where does Tom live?
Who cooked the soup?
What didn't the man do yesterday?
What is the man doing now?

answerOptions: They have to bargain on the sale.
The TV set is usually on sale.
They go to buy a TV set at a bargain price.
instances.correctAnswer: They go to buy a TV set at a bargain price.

variables.a: What does the woman suggest?

answerOptions: She wants to know how the man found the hotel.
She wants to know how the man likes the hotel.
She thinks the hotel is not very good.
instances.correctAnswer: She wants to know how the man likes the hotel.

variables.a: What does the woman mean?
What is the man doing now?

answerOptions: Ask her friends to come over.

variables.a: What will the woman probably do today?

answerOptions: He asks Anne to give him his passport and 2,000 dollars.
He asks Anne to bring her passport and less than 2,000 dollars.
He asks Anne to bring her passport and 2,000 dollars or more.
instances.correctAnswer: He asks Anne to bring her passport and 2,000 dollars or more.

variables.a: What does the man ask Anne to do?
